I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the request of the Government of Indonesia, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
fielded a Fact-Finding Mission in July 2005 to formulate technical assistance (TA)1 for the 
preparation of the Second Community and Local Government Support (CLGS II) Sector Project 
in Indonesia, in particular, to foster investment in community-level infrastructure to support local 
economic development and generate improved income opportunities. Mission members held 
discussions with officials of the National Development Planning Agency (Badan Perencanaan 
Pembangunan  Nasional  or  BAPPENAS),  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  and  provincial  and  local 
governments.2  Understanding  was  reached  on  the  objectives,  scope,  cost  estimates, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA. The design and monitoring 
framework is attached as Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Indonesia has achieved impressive poverty reduction in recent decades, despite the 
setbacks that occurred as a result of the 1997 Asian financial crisis. In 2004, at 16.7% of the 
population, the incidence of poverty was once again below precrisis levels; however, more than 
36 million people were living below the poverty line. In addition, a large proportion of the 
population is highly vulnerable to falling into poverty.3 The average poverty incidence figures 
further mask significant regional disparities.4  
 
3.  Indonesia still has one of the lowest levels of investment in infrastructure as a proportion 
of gross domestic product, especially by private entities.5 In 2003, Indonesia was ranked lowest 
among 30 countries, with populations in excess of 30 million, in relation to its physical and social 
infrastructure.6  All  sectors  face  significant  infrastructure  deficiencies.  Only  39%  of  urban 
populations are serviced by urban water supplies; road density levels are 1.6 kilometers per 
1,000 people; electricity consumption is just 319 kilowatt-hours per person per year, with 45% of 
households not connected to electricity; and only 3% of urban areas have fixed line telephones, 
with only 27 lines per 1,000 people.7 Problems include not just the lack of services, but the 
quality of services is poor, the level of maintenance is minimal, cost recovery of services are 
limited and nurture inequities, the regulatory framework is biased and inconsistent, and the 
capacity for funding infrastructure is limited. 
 
4.  The Government and ADB have extensive experience with community infrastructure 
development, participatory planning, and project implementation, as well as with local capacity 
development.  This  experience  has  been  gained  during  the  implementation  of  the  First 
Community and Local Government Support Project (CLGS I). CLGS I has achieved its targets 
and objectives, and the executing agency, BAPPENAS, demonstrated its capacity to efficiently 
implement  the  Project  by  supporting  the  construction  of  17,237  public  facilities  involving 
community efforts (type A projects) and an additional 3,076 community facilities using block 
grants. Infrastructure eligible for funding (type B projects) included (i) water supply, (ii) drainage, 
(iii) irrigation, (iv) local roads and bridges, (v) public toilets, (vi) markets, (vii) school buildings,

(viii) sanitation (solid waste handling or disposal), and (ix) water transport facilities such as piers 
and docks. The use of loan funds, which were provided as seed money, has been effective and 
efficient, and these community-based development efforts are known for their high degree of 
transparency. Communities have added substantially to the Project through additional noncash 
contributions, which have occasionally amounted to two or three times the value of project 
funding. Loan disbursement has been 97% and Government contributions have reached 96.6% 
of envisaged amounts.  
 
5.  Local  governments  have  demonstrated  their  strong  appreciation  of  CLGS  I  and  its 
contributions to village development. The 79 participating local governments have built new 
capacities in handling bottom-up development and in dealing with a large number of community 
groups. The communities, particularly local women’s organizations, have been a driving force 
for subproject identification, planning, and implementation. This confirms the availability of local 
knowledge and the capacity of communities and their organizations, which thereby reduces the 
need for technical or consultant backup. The contribution of communities can reduce the need 
for contractors, and supervision by communities reduces the costs of subprojects. Communities 
have been willing to commit to operating and maintaining facilities built under the Project. Thus 
the success of CLGS I on the one hand, and the continued poverty and need for infrastructure 
investment on the other hand, have prompted the Government’s request for CLGS II, to be 
implemented in other areas not covered by CLGS I, but within the main geographical focus of 
ADB’s country strategy and program (CSP).8  Lessons learnt under CLGS I will help in the 
formulation and implementation of CLGS II. 
 
6.  A strong linkage exists between poverty and lack of access to infrastructure. Improved 
local community infrastructure can result in better health and education, safe water supply and 
sanitation, and improved access to economic opportunities. All these are basic rights in the 
Government's  poverty  reduction  strategy  paper,  as  incorporated  into  the  Medium-Term 
Development Plan for 2005–2009. The provision of infrastructure for poor communities will also 
help achieve the Millennium Development Goals, namely, targets 1, 3, and 10.  
 
7.  Decentralization has led to significant changes in the Government’s approach to regional 
development. As the central Government no longer has the power or resources to directly 
support regional development, regions are forced to fund more of their own investment needs. 
In addition, the central Government has often directed investment toward regions that offer a 
competitive advantage to large corporations and investors to the exclusion of other regions. The 
proportion of private, especially foreign, investment in poorer regions is still low, and in most 
regions the capacity of institutions remains weak and inefficient. Hence CLGS II will not only 
face the challenge of providing investment for infrastructure development, but also of building 
the capacity of local governments and local community organizations, which are the facilitators 
and drivers of participatory development.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  TA  will  help  the  Government  identify  and  prepare  a  project  that  will  improve 
community members’ access to basic public infrastructure in poor urban, peri-urban, and rural 
areas and that will (i) increase employment and income opportunities, (ii) establish and/or 
                                                 
8  The current geographical focus includes North Sumatra, South Sumatra, Lampung, Banten, West Java, Central 
Java, Special Area of Yogyakarta, East Java, West Nusa Tengara, and Southeast Sulawesi. However, the revised 
CSP may redefine geographical focus.

3
strengthen community-based institutions, and (iii) improve local governments’ capacity to handle 
community-based development.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will help the Government prepare each project component and is structured to 
specifically address each of the components.9 The TA will analyze the feasibility of the new 
approach to providing community infrastructure provision through on-lending instead of on-
granting. It will help about 25 to 30 selected local governments (see the map)10 to prepare 
subproject appraisal reports (SPARs). Of these, three districts will be chosen as pilot areas 
based on the districts’ demonstrated commitment to pro-poor development and transparent and 
accountable governance, the participation of local stakeholders, and the demonstrated need. 
The TA will build on experience gained during CLGS I and will align this new project with other 
ADB-funded projects, including the Sustainable Capacity Building for Decentralization Project, 
the  Local  Government  Finance  and  Government  Reform  Sector  Development  Project,  the 
Community Water and Health Project, and the Decentralized Pro-Poor Budgeting and Service 
Delivery Project. As much as possible, CLGS II will be aligned and harmonized with the World 
Bank-funded Kecamatan Development Project and will avoid geographical overlap with it. The 
Project  supports  participatory,  decentralized  budgeting,  and  thereby  strengthens  the 
Government’s decentralization agenda and the sustainability of the community infrastructure 
development.  
 
10.  Part 1: Project Investment Design and Feasibility Analysis. These activities will lead 
to the design of a proposal for CLGS II. The project design will describe the policy of and 
strategy for providing poor communities in urban, peri-urban, and rural locations with access to 
infrastructure so as to improve local economic development and employment opportunities, 
promote the empowerment of local communities through inclusive participation in all stages of 
development planning and implementation, and build local government capacities to facilitate 
such  bottom-up  development  initiatives.  Due  consideration  will  be  given  to  technical, 
environmental,  social,  and  institutional  feasibility  and  the  economic  viability  and  financial 
sustainability of districts’ investments, taking into account impacts on poverty reduction and 
local  economic  development,  cost-recovery,  inability  to  recover  costs,  leverage  further 
investment, and operation and maintenance.  
 
11.  The format for local investment plans or SPARs will have six elements: (i) profile of 
communities,  recommended  service  standards,  and  priorities;  (ii)  preliminary  designs;  (iii) 
estimated  inputs  and  costs;  (iv)  plausible  subproject  financing,  including  central  and  local 
government, private sector, and community financing; (v) implementation arrangements, and 
(vi) implementation schedules. The average investment package will amount to approximately 
$3 million per district. The project design shall assure that CLGS II funds are well integrated with 
the decentralized mechanisms for budgeting and fund administration. Of particular importance for 
project preparation will be the participatory framework for project formulation, implementation 
and monitoring, and maintenance and the direct involvement of beneficiary communities and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs) based on the participatory planning, monitoring, and 
evaluation  methodology  already  developed  during  CLGS  I.  However,  because  CLGS  II 
subprojects are financed from the loan, detailed investment plans are required prior to CLGS II 
approval. This in turn affects the community participation process, which needs to be adapted 
and  converted  to  a  two-stage  process,  with  (i)  a  preliminary  planning  phase,  and  (ii)  a 
                                                 
9  Eligible CLGS II investment component include drinking water; washing, bathing, and toilet facilities; drainage; 
irrigation; markets; village roads and footpaths; bridges; boat piers and harbors; schools; health posts; and 
electricity connections. 
10 The selection of provinces will be aligned and consistent with the geographic focus of the CSP.

4   
mechanism for detailed action planning once subprojects are starting implementation. As the 
number of participating districts is fairly large, the TA will concentrate on three pilot districts for 
developing  a  comprehensive,  integrated,  and  participatory  SPAR  format  that  meets  ADB 
requirements; will guide and support the other 22 to 27 participating local governments in 
preparing  their  investment  plans;  and  will  interact  with  local  communities,  NGOs,  and 
community-based organizations during the formulation of SPARs. It is assumed that with the 
help of the TA consultants, participating local governments will be able to develop their own 
SPARs.11 The TA will also determine the requirements for implementing this part of the Project 
through a sector project. 
 
12.  Part  2:  Sector  Strengthening.  The  TA  will  review  the  existing  organizational  and 
financial framework for village-level or settlement-level infrastructure investments that will target 
the poor. Because the pattern of on-granting used for CLGS I is probably no longer applicable, 
CLGS II will need to establish either full or partial cost recovery as a basic principle. The 
interpretation and application of Ministry of Finance regulation KMK35/2003 will be critical for 
the  Project.  In  the  context  of  regulations  governing  the  financing  of  projects  under 
decentralization, the application this regulation is expected to lead to two types of funding 
arrangements for CLGS II, namely: (i) on-lending for cost-recovery subsectors, and (ii) on-
granting for noncost-recovery subsectors.12 The sector review will also include the compilation 
of baseline data regarding the preproject status of community infrastructure in the proposed 
districts and provinces. A review and adjustment of the participatory planning, monitoring, and 
evaluation approach of CLGS I and its modification under CLGS II resulting from the shift from 
block grants to the concept of SPAR preparation prior to project appraisal will necessitate 
adjustments of the CLGS community participation methodology. In addition, the sector review 
will  identify  core  capacity-building  requirements  of  participating  local  governments  for  the 
implementation of CLGS II.13 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $800,000 equivalent, comprising $200,000 in 
foreign exchange and $600,000 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested 
that ADB finance $600,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign currency cost and $400,000 
equivalent of local currency costs. The Government will finance the remaining local currency 
costs,  amounting  to  $200,000  equivalent,  which  will  cover  office  and  support  facilities, 
counterpart staff, administrative support, part of workshop expenses, report production and 
dissemination, and local transportation. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from ADB’s TA 
funding program. Details of the cost estimates and a financing plan are shown in Appendix 2. 
The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance 
any ensuing project. 
 
                                                 
11 The TA consultants will develop a system of workshops and technical support that will enable all candidate districts 
to formulate their draft SPARs in accordance with guidelines and formats developed in the three pilot districts. 
12 Cost recovery in certain subsectors where costs are recoverable will mean that community organizations will need 
to undertake additional tasks. The noncost-recovery subsectors may be funded by the national budget, by district 
or city budgets, or by other grant funding sources from bilateral donors. In accordance with the new directives of 
the Ministry of Finance, TA for project implementation, that is, expenses for consultants, community facilitators, and 
capacity-building activities, need to be downscaled and loan funding can only be used to a limited extent 
(tentatively 7–10% of a total investment package), which implies that other sources need to be mobilized.  
13 Local government capacity will be assessed prior to the incorporation of districts into the Project. The capacity 
mapping tools of the Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit-sponsored Support for Decentralization 
Measures will be recommended. ADB’s Regional Sustainable Development Department might be able to support the 
formulation and assessment of district capacities for CLGS II through a capacity-building project sponsored by the 
British Department for International Development, or an ADB-sponsored training program in Indonesia.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  BAPPENAS (deputy for infrastructure) will be the Executing Agency for this TA. A project 
management unit (PMU) to be established within BAPPENAS will organize the technical and 
administrative aspects of the TA. Suitably qualified and experienced counterpart staff will work 
alongside the TA consultants under the direction of the head of the PMU. The TA consultants 
will fully support the head of the PMU and will work in close collaboration with the counterpart 
team. The consultants will procure equipment for the TA and will hand this equipment over to 
the PMU when the final report is submitted. A steering committee, chaired by BAPPENAS and 
made up of senior officials of the Ministry of Public Works, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry 
of Home Affairs, and the Regional Autonomy Advisory Council, will be established to guide and 
oversee TA implementation. A working group chaired by Deputy Infrastructure of BAPPENAS, 
and consisting of representatives from BAPPENAS, the Ministry of Public Works, the Ministry of 
Finance, the Ministry of Home Affairs, and the Regional Autonomy Advisory Council and other 
nominated  representatives  of  regional  governments,  NGOs,  and  universities  will  provide 
counterpart support for the consultants.  
 
15.  The consultants for the Project will undertake a detailed feasibility assessment of the 
overall Project according to ADB policies and procedures. The TA report will provide a detailed 
explanation regarding cost recovery of subprojects and project description, including rationale 
and expected outcomes, benefits, and poverty impact analysis (Appendix 3); a fully developed 
logical  framework;  the  geographic  scope;  the  lending  modality  and  subsidiary  loan 
arrangements, if needed; and an assessment of implementing agencies along with estimates of 
inputs and costs and implementation arrangements and schedule. All subcomponents will be 
analyzed,  as  appropriate,  for  technical,  financial,  economic,  social,  environmental,  and 
institutional viability and sustainability. The TA will also undertake on-the-job and formal training 
of pertinent national agencies and local governments.  
 
16.  The TA will require a minimum input of 8 person-months of international and 38 person-
months of domestic consulting services with expertise in community development, management 
information systems, civil engineering, financial analysis, regional development planning, and 
procurement. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants, using the quality- and cost-based selection method and other arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. All procurement under the TA will follow 
ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Procurement.  The  consultants  will  be  based  in  Jakarta  and  will  be 
expected to travel as necessary to the regions. The proposed outline terms of reference for the 
consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
17.  The TA is expected to begin in November 2005 and be implemented over 6 months, with 
the final report produced in May 2006 and with intermittent inputs supporting project appraisal 
thereafter. Tripartite reviews will be held after inception, at the time of the first interim report, and 
at  the  draft  final  report  stage.  Corresponding  to  these  reviews,  stakeholder  consultation 
workshops will be held to present progress to, and obtain input from, central Government 
agencies, local governments, civil society, and representatives of the communities involved. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia for preparing the Second Community and Local Government 
Support Sector Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Indonesia: 
The Project will have direct poverty reduction effects on its beneficiaries, as it will improve access to social and 
productive infrastructure facilities in urban, peri-urban, and rural communities. The infrastructure components will help 
to  improve  livelihoods,  local  economic  activities,  and  household  incomes.  Through  these  initiatives,  project 
beneficiaries will have access to additional or improved income sources and will be able to reduce their transaction 
costs and maximize their existing resources. The Project will also involve community participation and lead to the 
empowerment of participating community groups and will strengthen the capacities of local governments to facilitate 
such participatory processes. Increased participation of the poor is one of the 10 goals of the Government's poverty 
reduction strategy paper.  
  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                         Proposed Poverty Classification: Targeted intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
Poverty analysis will be an integral part of subproject selection and design and will be based on quantitative and 
qualitative methodologies. Subproject selection will consider sector data and country-, region-, and subproject-level 
poverty data and will involve local-level poverty assessments and stakeholder consultations. Subproject planning and 
design will entail intensive qualitative analysis directly involving project beneficiaries through the extensive use of 
participatory methods to identify the local poor population and the infrastructure provisions that may better fit their 
needs. Two multistakeholder workshops will be held to discuss subproject formulation and implementation and 
another round of community consultations will be held following the approval of the subprojects.

D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Women will be fully represented in participatory design to ensure that community infrastructure provisions reflect 
women’s role in the domestic economy and that health and income generation benefits reflect women’s needs. 
Particular attention to women will be also given in the location of social infrastructure facilities (water, sanitation, solid 
waste management, health posts, and so on). A gender plan will be prepared.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will comprise two parts: part 1, the project investment 
design and feasibility analysis component, and part 2, the sector strengthening component. 
 
B.  Consulting Services 
 
2.  The consultants’ tasks are outlined for each part. 
 
  1.  Part 1:  Project Investment Design and Feasibility Analysis  
 
3.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks in relation to part 1:  
(i)  Prepare a proposal for the Second Community and Local Government Support 
(CLGS  II)  Project  that  comprises  a  policy  component  and  an  investment 
component  for  physical  infrastructure  at  the  community  level  based  on  the 
findings  of  the  statistical  and  econometric  analysis  and  the  independent 
evaluation1 of CLGS I. Describe the Project’s objectives with due consideration to 
its technical, environmental, social, and institutional feasibility and taking into 
account its impacts on poverty reduction and local economic development, its 
cost-recovery  and  noncost-recovery  aspects,  and  its  leverage  for  further 
investment as well as its operation and maintenance. 
 
(ii)  Determine the appropriate eligibility, project readiness criteria, and procedures 
for subprojects based on the foregoing. The selection of local governments shall 
ensure that there is no duplication of efforts funded by the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) or other agencies. 
 
(iii)  Help the executing agency select participating local governments in a number of 
predetermined provinces2 and assess their poverty ratios, fiscal capacity, and 
indebtedness. 
 
(iv)  Help the executing agency with the activities required to familiarize candidate 
local governments with the Project‘s objectives and parameters and the criteria to 
be  applied  during  the  assessment  of  the  readiness  of  candidate  local 
governments. 
 
(v)  Assess local government capacity, willingness, and readiness to participate in 
CLGS II under the modalities of on-lending and on-granting, as stipulated under 
Ministry of Finance regulation KMK 35/2003, and with the condition that they 
mobilize additional national and/or local contributions and assess and adapt the 
latest changes in Government policy with regard to applying these guidelines.

(SPARs) for three pilot districts.3 The SPAR format shall be user-friendly and

(viii)  Prepare a participatory framework for project formulation, implementation and

(ix)  Guide and support all 25–30 selected local governments4 in the preparation of

involuntary resettlement safeguard requirements.

development  plan,  or  specific  action  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  policy  on

(ii)  Prepare a detailed project cost estimate, assuming a sector project modality

2.  Part 2: Sector Strengthening  
 
5.  The consultants will undertake the following activities in relation to part 2:  
(i)  Review the existing organizational and financial framework for pro-poor village-
level and settlement-level infrastructure investment.  
 
(ii)  Undertake  a  financial  management  assessment  of  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies that should include (a) corporate planning and budgetary 
control,  (b)  financial  and  management  accounting,  (c)  cost  accounting,  (d) 
internal control and audit system, and (e) data processing. Suggest appropriate 
financial covenants to monitor the Project’s financial conditionalities. The purpose 
of the financial management assessment is to ensure that financial management 
arrangements proposed for the Project are satisfactory and that the implementing 
agencies have the financial management capacity to sustain project investments 
over  time.  Based  on  financial  analysis  and  the  financial  management 
assessment, draw conclusions with respect to financial viability and long-term 
financial  sustainability.  Identify  risks  that  could  affect  project  implementation 
and/or sustainability and identify appropriate risk mitigation measures. Financial 
analysis  and  financial  management  assessment  should  be  undertaken  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on Financial Management and Analysis of 
Projects. 
 
(iii)  Compile baseline data on community infrastructure in the proposed or selected 
districts. 
 
(iv)  Conduct  a  review  of  the  participatory  planning,  monitoring,  and  evaluation 
approach of CLGS and its modification under CLGS II necessitated by the shift

(v)  Identify  core  capacity-building  requirements  resulting  from  the  foregoing

(vi)  In addition, the consultants will help the executing agency liaise with Australian,

C.  Staffing 
 
6.  The consulting firm will provide 8 person-months of international consultant input. One 
consultant can cover more than one field of expertise. All international consultants should have 
relevant regional experience, preferably in Indonesia, and have excellent command of the 
Indonesian language. One of the international consultants, in addition to providing technical 
expertise, will act as the team leader. The consulting firm will also provide 38 person-months of 
domestic  input.  One  of  the  domestic  consultants  will  act  as  the  deputy  team  leader.  The 
international  consultants  will  consist  of  (i)  a  team  leader/civil  engineer  or  community 
development specialist or regional development specialist (6–9 months), and (ii) a financial and 
economic  analyst  (2  months).  The  domestic  consultants  will  consist  of  (i)  a  financial  and 
economic analyst (6 months), (ii) a community development specialist (6 months), (iii) a civil 
engineer (6 months), (iv) a regional development and management information specialist (6 
months), and (v) a procurement specialist (2 months).  
 
7.  The  consultants  must  demonstrate  adequate  knowledge  of  project  preparation  in 
accordance with ADB and Government standards and should have experience with community-
based  projects  (including  participatory  planning,  monitoring,  and  evaluation),  relevant 
Government regulations in the context of decentralization and regional autonomy, and the 
Ministry of Finance’s regulation KMK 35/2003 on on-lending and on-granting.  
 
8.  The duration of the assignment will be 6–9 months; however, not all disciplines will be 
required  for  the  full  length  of  the  assignment.  Proposals  with  staggered  inputs  may  be 
necessary to accommodate possible delays during SPAR preparation. 
 
D.  Reporting  
 
9.  The consultants will submit the following reports in hard and soft copy versions: (i) an 
inception report within 4 weeks of commencing the TA; (ii) a draft project design paper within 2 
months; (iii) an interim report, including preliminary SPARs, within 4 months; (iv) a draft final 
report including a draft financing plan for CLGS II, after 5.5 months; (v) a final report, including 
the draft project document for ADB Board approval (the report and recommendation of the 
President) 2 weeks after receiving comments from ADB and the Government on the draft final 
report; and (vi) other reports as may reasonably be required.
